comments.commentBody: Amen.

Amen.

To add insult to injury, on September 9th Mitt Romney told "Meet the Press":
"I’m not in this race to slow the rise of the oceans or to heal the planet. I’m in this race to help the American people."

So, essentially, Mitt doesn't believe in slowing the rise of the oceans, healing the planet, OR having a department of the Federal Government specifically tasked with coordinating relief efforts once a sick ecosystem begins acting out.

But he nonetheless claims that he's in this race to help "people" - as opposed to gratifying his immense ego and ungodly lust for power.

As the saying goes, I may have been born at night, but it wasn't last night.
I like it!!! We New Yorkers look at the canyon fires, earthquakes and mudslides much the same way.  No malice - just an observation.
I think sometimes ships go out to sea a bit during a storm to stop from being crashed against the shore. If it's in open water, it could be safer. It doesn't help when the storm is this big though.

Down South, they let us know via radio, TV. If you no electricity, you probably have 12-24 hrs. of potable water; if by 24 hrs you've not gotten any info from authorities, I'd boil just in case.... but, hey,you guys should have plenty of backup, I'd think. We start keeping water in the bathtubs to flush with.. and we always stock up w/bottled water... Really I'd be surprised if you need this advice.

Our power folks w/trucks are heading ur way. Our guys are good at this.

Stay calm, and stay safe!

Yes if it's the same one I parked in. I was going to leave on a flight this morning but I was staying in Manhattan so I parked my car there earlier this weekend. After my flight was cancelled I had to move my car because the guy called me to ask me if I could take it.

Right, well as of 9:51 it was pretty much over.

As for the rest of the world, those events tend to be common and recurring. When big events happen that are out of the ordinary (like Christchurch, NZ for example, or the entire state of Texas catching on fire), people pay lots of attention to it and the folks affected -- who have never experienced such a thing -- tend to get worked up about it.
23rd st under 5ft of wate near 10th ave.

You ask "Why should we give it (i.e., Israel) special consideration, just because it is called 'the Jewish state'?" Please understand that the reason our politicians give Israel special consideration has very little to do with American Jews and much more to do with Christian Zionists. That movement, strongly intertwined with Evangelical Christianity in the United States, has tens of millions of interested voters. Perhaps a factor of 10 to 20 times greater than the Jewish population of the US. I recently spoke to a woman, an Evangelical, who told me with great sincerity that she says a prayer for the safety and health of Israel every evening before she goes to sleep. US politicians give Israel special consideration because it is fundamental to the religious life of Evangelical Christians, not because they are in support of the wishes of a very small Jewish population.

Well said sir - my mother was born in the outer Hebrides and spoken Gaelic as her mother tongue,  my ethnic/religious background is Presbyterian Scot, my ideological basis is the 'Edinburgh Enlightenment' and nothing could be more antithetical to my views on Canadian foreign policy than the idea that it should be driven by a misconceived and divisive idea about  Scottish nationalist concerns or ethnic loyalties on the part of the Sottish diaspora.  The obvious danger of infecting domestic politics with intractable foreign conflicts is plainly visible to all but the wilfully blind. You don't even have to go to the questions of justice and reality content to come to such a view.
Well, it's eye-opening, to say the least, that 78 people agree with your dog-whistle-style accusation that American Jews are duplicitous and not to be trusted.

I'm wholly supportive of progressive Jews who don't want support for Israel to put Romney in the White House. But let's do a little thought experiment. Imagine that Japanese-Americans in large numbers, supported by the handful of Japanese-Americans in Congress, actively sought to influence American policy so that Washington strongly backed Japan's claims to territories also claimed by China and Korea, condoned the refusal of conservative Japanese leaders to express contrition for atrocities committed by Japan during the Pacific War, and frequently referred to Japan's Korean and Chinese neighbors using disparaging and even racist terms. Let's say that a Japanese-American lobbying group gave huge amounts of money to one or both of our major parties, in order to make sure that Washington's ties with Tokyo remained close and friendly. Frequently, they might use the language: "we Japanese are the divine race," just as Jews call themselves "the Chosen People."

This of course is not true: Japanese-Americans have always made it clear that although they are proud of their culture, they are Americans first, and that they support America's interests even when they contravene Tokyo's (I know, because I live in Hawaii, which has a large Japanese-American population).

Japan is a foreign state; we owe it no loyalty, although we shouldn't do its people harm. Israel is also a state. Why should we give it special consideration, just because it is called "the Jewish state"?
You're missing a tunnel.  There are the Lincoln, the Holland, and the Brooklyn Battery, which the newsyappers keep reminding us is now (officially) called the Hugh Carey Tunnel.
The Lincoln tunnel apparently stayed open throughout, probably because both approaches are protected by higher ground.

I intended to say that I thought there was too much crosswordese, but I see that Lasz felt it wasn't a problem.
He mentioned EMO, AMAT and OGEE. What about ERITU, OBIS, TIOS, CROC, ENOL,ELOI, ADUE?(The last time Lasz and I disagreed on this issue, our positions were reversed, btw.)

But still a good job, Alex V. The left, middle, right arrangement of the various political persuasions was certainly cleverly done, and I don't see how he could have gotten Progressives situated (nor Libertarians, nor some of the other less traditional folks).

So the Numberplay puzzle of the week should be to figure out how long it takes thousands of power company repairers to restore about 5 MILLION customers. Boggles the mind. And I hadn't thought about the two NY tunnels -- anybody have a submarine?

You should only need to break one link.

If you break a link not on the end of the chain, you will get three lengths of chain:

One of length 1 (the broken link); A short chain of length X; and a long chain of length 12-X.

Because lengths of chain can be placed on either side of the balance, they can add or subtract from the total.

For each weight W that can be measured using the two longer lengths, we can also measure W+1 and W-1, using the single length chain.

We will always have W=0 (use neither longer chain), and W=12 (use both). We will also have: W=X,12-X and 12-2X.

Since each value of W, gets us three consecutive weights, and we already have W=0 and W=12, W=3,6, and 9 will cover the entire range.

And indeed X=3 gives us lengths of 3 and 9 which combined can measure 0 [neither], 3 [short], 6 [long-short], 9 [long] and 12 [short + long], thus allowing us to measure the entire integral range from -1 to 13 once we add back in the single link.

-1 may not be altogether useful...

My company is in the early stages of designing a mobile app and we had many discussions about how we could create the right design if we had to follow the fake naugahyde and resin-coated icons. John Ive has been designing ever increasingly elegant and sleek hardware without tricks while the interface was going 180 degrees in the opposite direction. This bodes well for better mobile apps -- I know my design team will be very happy about this.

I would also remind everyone of the private sector's involvement in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. Does Blackwater ring a bell anyone?

http://www.motherjones.com/environment/2009/08/secret-history-hurricane-...
Let any state who wants to opt out of FEMA and do its own emergency management do so. Think there will be any takers?

Mr. Romney said nothing of the sort, but he might have rebutted your claim  by simply pointing out how ill-prepared FEMA was in handling  Katrina, and that was because FEMA had just recently embedding in a huge new bureaucrary.  Mr. Obama seems to think this is the way to go. He would “solve” our educational problems by hiring 100,000 new math and science teachers.  As if  these could be conjured up out of thin air, and even if they could, have any effct on outcomes in a short while. This is magical thinking.

Some things must be centralized and coordinated from Washington. Emergency response to disaster is one most people associate with our Federal government and not, as Mr. Romney said a year ago, the states.

Even with the tremendous help of FEMA. the affected states will still need as many hands as the unaffected states can spare. Tonight, Governor Jerry Brown declared that California will assist states in the wake of Sandy.

In the absence of FEMA, it is unthinkable that large-scale disaster would be left up to whatever aid arrives from volunteers and other states. It is unthinkable that any state might not get all the help it needs from its government. Yet, that is precisely what Mitt Romney advocates whenever he talks about states' rights.

Our nation is a federation of states, with a central government in Washington, DC. That is how we are set up. The discussion about how our government works was settled some time ago. For Mr. Romney and the Libertarians in and outside his party to say otherwise, and perhaps jeopardize our republic, is simply un-American.

Didn't see the question. It's an acronym for Stupid Wilda__ Guess.

Fireman talk. :-

Mac

I'm not really seeing it any longer. There are some corporate policies in place, but it seems to be mostly lip service. My company pushed "cool biz," but everyone still showed up in suits and ties, and the air conditioning stayed on all summer (as did the elevators, etc.). We continue to fly/train all over the country every day to meet with university professors when it could easily be done via a video conference. There was talk last year about letting people work from home or from community-based work places, but it never happened.

In my neighborhood, three houses in the last year have been knocked down and rebuilt, and the replacements were larger and with no evidence of any energy efficient building materials or architectural strategies.

I do believe people are buying more energy-efficient appliances. We are a nation of extreme consumption (people routinely line up at the department stores in Shibuya fifteen minutes before opening to buy $50 boxes of sweets or "rare, limited foods"), and it will always be easier to buy something new than to actually remove the appliance all together. I can't speak for the rest of Japan, but our TEPCO rates have been raised twice in the last year. I imagine that will have a larger impact than any government policy--unfortunately the people who will be forced into bearing the brunt of the conservation will be the poorer class.
Intelligent mobile phone really convenience to our life, but ordinary mobile phone also have the value of existence
Good advice! and Go Beavers!

Suhail,

At its best, New York City is a community, so the issue is not as simple as the wind speed in Central Park. Lower Manhattan is flooded, 250,000 are without power, major hospitals are being evacuated, low-lying parts of the outer boroughs are inundated, as are parts of our tunnel and subway systems, and the shoreline is being rearranged in New Jersey and Long Island.

Furthermore, it is far from being over: we're still expecting to go through a second high tide.

So I think you're the one who is hiding in a concrete-reinforced ostrich suit.

Jen, you really should stop reporting every rumor that's been posted on the internet. The NYSE has not been flooded. No 100 mph gusts reported by credible weather stations. In fact, you'll have a tough time finding ANY credible weather station that has recorded 2 minute average 74 MPH winds during that last 24 hours. That is the standard for a hurricane. Don't even try to find a record of sustained 90 MPH ground level winds as NOAA was claiming.

Sandy is a big storm - a big tropical, now post tropical storm. But it's strength has been exaggerated. This has become standard procedures for government agencies wanting more funding.
Gerry has a point --- we in Mnhattan might be without lights for 12 hours and the Whole Foods and Starbucks might not reopen until Wednesday.  Ohnthe horror!!!

Yes, that's right! In 1938 nobody died! We were much, much hardier then.

Oh no hang on. That hurricane killed 800 people.
it would help if you specify what part of brooklyn
Harriet was in 1956.  The hurricane in 1938 was just called The Great New England Hurricane, or the hurricane of 1938.

Please forgive this off-topic comment. It was posted in the wrong place.

My heart is with everyone who is suffering from this devastating storm, especially those whose lives are at risk helping others. Please stay as safe as possible.
That was not Hurricane Harriet.  Harriet was in 1956.  They didn't start naming storms until 1945.

Ok Suhail, you are really not getting it. In NYC major problem is surge, not wind nor rain. except the 57 street crane practically not that much damage in Manhattan, BUT surge and flood wreak havoc tunnels and subway.

This is a city 8 million is living 17 million is one way or another working. yes what happened is importnat even the numeric value of Hurricane very low.
